<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 119, 380, 146]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSEâ„¢

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 171, 184, 189]]<|/det|>
PHYSICS Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[891, 172, 908, 186]]<|/det|>
0625/22

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[783, 193, 907, 209]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025 45 minutes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 248, 509, 266]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 279, 438, 296]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 306, 540, 323]]<|/det|>
Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 351, 603, 379]]<|/det|>
- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. - For each question there are four possible answers \(\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\). Choose the one you consider correct

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 380, 682, 397]]<|/det|>
and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet. - Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 413, 277, 430]]<|/det|>
- Write in soft pencil. - Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 441, 521, 459]]<|/det|>
spaces provided unless this has been done for you. - Do not use correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 472, 366, 489]]<|/det|>
- Do not write on any bar codes. - You may use a calculator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 503, 680, 524]]<|/det|>
- Take the weight of 1.0 kg to be 9.8 N (acceleration of free fall \(=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\) ).

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 548, 222, 565]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION - The total mark for this paper is 40 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 579, 446, 594]]<|/det|>
- Each correct answer will score one mark. - Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 896, 91]]<|/det|>
1 Which instrument is most suitable to determine the volume of a small irregularly shaped stone?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 247, 116]]<|/det|>
A 30 cm ruler

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 128, 250, 143]]<|/det|>
B digital timer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 154, 311, 169]]<|/det|>
C measuring cylinder

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 179, 269, 193]]<|/det|>
D tape measure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 224, 805, 241]]<|/det|>
2 A steel ball is dropped from the top floor of a building. Air resistance can be ignored.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 255, 526, 266]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes the motion of the ball?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 281, 482, 298]]<|/det|>
A The ball falls with constant acceleration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 308, 432, 323]]<|/det|>
B The ball falls with constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 333, 454, 350]]<|/det|>
C The ball falls with decreasing speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 359, 496, 375]]<|/det|>
D The ball falls with increasing acceleration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 404, 748, 421]]<|/det|>
3 The diagram shows a velocity-time graph for an object which is accelerating.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 433, 704, 690]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 706, 435, 721]]<|/det|>
What is the acceleration of the object?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 731, 236, 748]]<|/det|>
A \(0.40 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 731, 393, 748]]<|/det|>
B \(2.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 731, 559, 748]]<|/det|>
C \(3.0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 731, 731, 748]]<|/det|>
D \(100 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|> 4 Diagram 1 shows a piece of flexible material that contains many pockets of air. Diagram 2 shows the same piece of flexible material after it has been compressed so that its volume decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 115, 455, 131]]<|/det|> diagram 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 131, 451, 149]]<|/det|> (before compression) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 131, 722, 149]]<|/det|> diagram 2 (after compression) <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 175, 427, 240]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 160, 727, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 271, 869, 288]]<|/det|> What happens to the mass and to the weight of the flexible material when it is compressed? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 298, 459, 428]]<|/det|>
mass
weight
A
increases
increases
B
increases
no change
C
no change
increases
D
no change
no change
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 454, 477, 473]]<|/det|> 5 A student determines the density of copper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 484, 440, 503]]<|/det|> She has a rectangular block of copper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 513, 446, 532]]<|/det|> Which other apparatus does she need? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[113, 542, 819, 671]]<|/det|>
balance
ruler

\(\checkmark\)
\(\checkmark\)

key

\(\checkmark\)
\(\checkmark\)
\(\chi\)
\(\chi\)

\(\checkmark\)
\(\chi\)
\(\chi\)
\(\chi\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[194, 550, 267, 565]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 574, 153, 591]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 601, 153, 616]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 626, 153, 641]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 652, 153, 667]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 698, 543, 717]]<|/det|> 6 A 0.15 kg mass is suspended from a vertical spring. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 729, 918, 747]]<|/det|> The mass is pulled downwards until the spring has extended by 12 cm from its unstretched length. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 772, 482, 791]]<|/det|> The spring constant of the spring is \(30 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 803, 785, 822]]<|/det|> What is the magnitude of the initial acceleration of the spring when it is released? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 830, 222, 847]]<|/det|> A \(14 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 830, 388, 847]]<|/det|> B \(24 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 830, 554, 847]]<|/det|> C \(28 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 830, 722, 847]]<|/det|> D \(34 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 621, 91]]<|/det|> 7 A cricket ball of mass 0.15 kg is moving at a speed of \(30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 105, 918, 120]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a batsman holding a bat stationary as the ball hits the bat and bounces back at the same speed in the opposite direction. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 148, 515, 166]]<|/det|> The ball is in contact with the bat for \(1.0 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~s}\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 179, 693, 304]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 318, 918, 334]]<|/det|> The table shows the change in momentum of the ball and the magnitude of the force applied to the ball. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 365, 296, 379]]<|/det|> Which row is correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 392, 594, 536]]<|/det|>
change of momentum
\(\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\)
force applied to ball/N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 567, 598, 583]]<|/det|> 8 A stone is thrown vertically upwards at a speed of \(5.0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 597, 918, 612]]<|/det|> All of the energy initially in the kinetic store of the stone is transferred to its gravitational potential store when the stone reaches its maximum height. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 642, 670, 657]]<|/det|> Which equation gives the maximum height \(h\) reached by the stone? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 675, 256, 706]]<|/det|> A \(\quad h=\frac{9.8}{2 \times 5.0^{2}}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 720, 261, 751]]<|/det|> B \(\quad h=\frac{5.0^{2} \times 2}{9.8}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 767, 247, 798]]<|/det|> C \(\quad h=\frac{5.0^{2}}{2 \times 9.8}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 813, 256, 846]]<|/det|> D \(\quad h=\frac{2 \times 9.8}{5.0^{2}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 402, 91]]<|/det|> 9 Three energy resources are listed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 103, 322, 118]]<|/det|> 1 geothermal <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 129, 267, 143]]<|/det|> 2 wind <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 156, 325, 170]]<|/det|> 3 nuclear fuel <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 185, 513, 202]]<|/det|> Which resources get their energy from the Sun? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 213, 239, 228]]<|/det|> A 1,2 and 3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 213, 455, 228]]<|/det|> B 1 and 2 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 213, 590, 228]]<|/det|> C 1 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 213, 708, 228]]<|/det|> D 2 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 259, 715, 274]]<|/det|> 10 A sample of a substance has a shape that is determined by its container. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 482, 305]]<|/det|> What are the possible states of this sample? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 316, 322, 333]]<|/det|> A gas, liquid and solid <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 343, 311, 360]]<|/det|> B gas and liquid only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 368, 306, 384]]<|/det|> C gas and solid only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 394, 319, 411]]<|/det|> D solid and liquid only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 439, 682, 456]]<|/det|> 11 A stationary smoke particle is hit by a fast-moving nitrogen molecule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 469, 918, 485]]<|/det|> Which row describes the motion of the smoke particle and of the nitrogen molecule after the collision? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 511, 573, 640]]<|/det|>
smoke particle
nitrogen molecule
A
moves
rebounds
B
moves
stops
C
remains stationary
rebounds
D
remains stationary
stops

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 590, 91]]<|/det|> 12 A bubble of gas rises from the bottom of a lake to the top. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 888, 120]]<|/det|> The table shows readings of the gas pressure inside the bubble and the volume of the bubble. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 547, 150]]<|/det|> The temperature of the water in the lake is constant. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 166, 736, 181]]<|/det|> The values in three rows of the table are correct and one row is not correct. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 195, 333, 210]]<|/det|> Which row is not correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 222, 482, 351]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 379, 918, 396]]<|/det|> 13 The diagram shows a glass flask sealed with a small volume of mercury in a glass tube. When the flask is gently warmed, the mercury rises up the tube. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[375, 421, 625, 667]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 679, 590, 696]]<|/det|> What is the main cause of the movement of the mercury? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 708, 380, 724]]<|/det|> A expansion of air in the flask <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 734, 382, 750]]<|/det|> B expansion of the glass flask <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 759, 380, 776]]<|/det|> C expansion of the glass tube <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 784, 366, 801]]<|/det|> D expansion of the mercury

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
14 The diagram shows the equipment used in an experiment to determine the specific heat capacity of a metal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 121, 921, 136]]<|/det|>
In the experiment, a heater is switched on for \(t \mathrm{~s}\) and the increase in temperature \(\Delta \theta\) of a block of the metal is measured in \(^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[261, 166, 738, 361]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 378, 620, 393]]<|/det|>
Which equation gives the specific heat capacity of the metal?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 409, 234, 441]]<|/det|>
A \(c=\frac{P}{t m \Delta \theta}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[283, 409, 396, 441]]<|/det|>
B \(c=\frac{P t}{m \Delta \theta}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 408, 567, 441]]<|/det|>
C \(c=\frac{t m \Delta \theta}{P}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 408, 730, 441]]<|/det|>
D \(c=\frac{m \Delta \theta}{P t}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 678, 91]]<|/det|> 15 The diagram shows four rods. Each rod is made of a different metal. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[333, 102, 667, 322]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 339, 692, 354]]<|/det|> Wax is used to attach small metal balls at the rod ends \(P, Q, R\) and \(S\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 369, 811, 385]]<|/det|> Each rod is the same size. They are heated uniformly by a Bunsen burner at point \(X\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 398, 584, 415]]<|/det|> As the rods warm up, the wax melts and the balls fall off. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 427, 479, 444]]<|/det|> Why does the ball on the silver rod fall first? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 456, 446, 473]]<|/det|> A Silver is the best conductor of heat. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 482, 454, 499]]<|/det|> B Silver is the worst conductor of heat. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 507, 432, 524]]<|/det|> C Silver is the best radiator of heat. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 533, 434, 550]]<|/det|> D Silver is the worst radiator of heat. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 579, 753, 596]]<|/det|> 16 Three solid copper spheres, \(X, Y\) and \(Z\), are heated to the same temperature. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[300, 607, 700, 712]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 664, 91]]<|/det|>
21 A ray of light, travelling in air, is incident on an air-glass boundary.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 105, 808, 120]]<|/det|>
The angles between the incident ray, the refracted ray and the boundary are shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[350, 133, 648, 261]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 275, 697, 292]]<|/det|>
Which equation is used to calculate the refractive index \(n\) of the glass?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 306, 245, 339]]<|/det|>
A \(n=\frac{\sin 40^{\circ}}{\sin 26^{\circ}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 306, 413, 339]]<|/det|>
B \(n=\frac{\sin 40^{\circ}}{\sin 64^{\circ}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 306, 579, 339]]<|/det|>
C \(n=\frac{\sin 50^{\circ}}{\sin 26^{\circ}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 306, 745, 339]]<|/det|>
D \(n=\frac{\sin 50^{\circ}}{\sin 64^{\circ}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 371, 846, 387]]<|/det|>
22 A small object O is placed near a converging lens, as shown. The lens forms an image I .

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[334, 400, 664, 534]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 544, 350, 559]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 572, 372, 588]]<|/det|>
A The image I is diminished.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 599, 350, 616]]<|/det|>
B The image I is inverted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 626, 316, 642]]<|/det|>
C The image I is real.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 652, 617, 668]]<|/det|>
D The object O is closer to the lens than its principal focus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 698, 490, 714]]<|/det|>
23 What is the approximate speed of light in air?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 726, 225, 741]]<|/det|>
A \(300 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 752, 234, 767]]<|/det|>
B \(300 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 776, 267, 794]]<|/det|>
C \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 804, 277, 821]]<|/det|>
D \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 780, 91]]<|/det|>
24 A ship sends an ultrasound pulse to the seabed to measure the depth of the sea.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 590, 120]]<|/det|>
The speed of ultrasound waves in sea water is \(1500 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 719, 151]]<|/det|>
The pulse takes 4.6 seconds to travel to the seabed and back to the ship.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 164, 361, 181]]<|/det|>
What is the depth of the sea?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 191, 206, 206]]<|/det|>
A 330 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 191, 372, 206]]<|/det|>
B 650 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 191, 548, 206]]<|/det|>
C 3500 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 191, 715, 206]]<|/det|>
D 6900 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 236, 649, 253]]<|/det|>
25 A dolphin has a range of audible frequencies of 150 Hz - 150 kHz .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 267, 891, 284]]<|/det|>
Which range of frequencies can be heard both by humans with good hearing and by dolphins?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 295, 269, 310]]<|/det|>
A 20 Hz - 150 Hz

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 278, 337]]<|/det|>
B 20 Hz - 150 kHz

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 346, 289, 362]]<|/det|>
C 20 kHz - 150 kHz

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 372, 279, 388]]<|/det|>
D 150 Hz - 20 kHz

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 418, 918, 434]]<|/det|>
26 A positively charged balloon is placed against a wall. The charge makes the balloon stick to the wall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 462, 377, 479]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 642, 506]]<|/det|>
A Positive charges on the balloon attract electrons in the wall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 515, 628, 532]]<|/det|>
B Positive charges on the balloon attract protons in the wall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 540, 630, 557]]<|/det|>
C Positive charges on the balloon repel electrons in the wall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 567, 620, 583]]<|/det|>
D Positive charges on the balloon repel protons in the wall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 614, 908, 629]]<|/det|>
27 A student is trying to determine the resistance of a lamp. He sets up the incorrect circuit shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 642, 603, 744]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 755, 918, 771]]<|/det|>
Which change would allow him to take the measurements needed to calculate the resistance of the lamp?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 800, 640, 816]]<|/det|>
A Disconnect the ammeter and move it to the left of the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 825, 697, 842]]<|/det|>
B Swap the positions of the ammeter and the voltmeter in the circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 851, 680, 867]]<|/det|>
C Disconnect the ammeter and connect it in parallel with the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 877, 682, 893]]<|/det|>
D Disconnect the voltmeter and connect it in parallel with the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 402, 89]]<|/det|> 28 A metallic wire \(X\) has a resistance. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 764, 119]]<|/det|> What is the difference in resistance for a wire of the same material as \(X\) that is: <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 135, 532, 149]]<|/det|> - shorter than \(X\) but the same diameter <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 160, 637, 176]]<|/det|> - the same length as \(X\) but with a smaller diameter? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 188, 587, 336]]<|/det|>
resistance of
shorter wire
resistance of wire
with smaller diameter
A
greater
greater
B
greater
smaller
C
smaller
greater
D
smaller
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 217, 145, 232]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 243, 153, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 269, 153, 284]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 294, 153, 310]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 321, 153, 336]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 361, 547, 379]]<|/det|> 29 The diagram shows the circuit for a potential divider. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[378, 390, 620, 548]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 558, 446, 576]]<|/det|> Which equation is used to calculate \(V_{1}\) ? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 588, 125, 605]]<|/det|> A <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[132, 588, 267, 621]]<|/det|> \(V_{1}=\frac{R_{1}}{V_{2} \times\left(R_{1}+R_{2}\right)}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 638, 267, 671]]<|/det|> B \(\quad V_{1}=\frac{V_{2} \times R_{1}}{R_{2}}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 685, 267, 720]]<|/det|> C \(\quad V_{1}=\frac{V_{2} \times R_{1}}{R_{1}+R_{2}}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 737, 267, 772]]<|/det|> D \(\quad V_{1}=\frac{R_{1}}{V_{2} \times R_{2}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 559, 89]]<|/det|>
30 Which electrical device is used to convert a.c. to d.c.?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 101, 201, 115]]<|/det|>
A diode

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 128, 195, 143]]<|/det|>
B relay

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 154, 238, 168]]<|/det|>
C thermistor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 179, 250, 192]]<|/det|>
D transformer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 224, 918, 241]]<|/det|>

33 The primary voltage supplied to a transformer is 3.0 V . The secondary voltage is 5.0 V and the secondary current is 2.0 A . The transformer is 100\% efficient.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 618, 501, 635]]<|/det|>
What is the primary current in the transformer?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 648, 198, 662]]<|/det|>
A 1.2 A

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 648, 363, 662]]<|/det|>
B 2.0 A

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 648, 532, 663]]<|/det|>
C 3.3 A

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 648, 697, 663]]<|/det|>
D 7.5 A

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 693, 918, 709]]<|/det|>
34 When a thin gold foil is bombarded with alpha particles, some alpha particles are deflected through large angles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 739, 460, 754]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains this deflection?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 767, 501, 785]]<|/det|>
A Most of the atom consists of empty space.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 792, 918, 809]]<|/det|>
B All of the positive charge and most of the mass of the gold atom are concentrated in a small volume.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 833, 733, 851]]<|/det|>
C Positive charge in the gold atom is spread evenly throughout the atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 860, 601, 876]]<|/det|>
D All of the negative charge is concentrated at its centre.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 753, 91]]<|/det|>
35 A detector near a radioactive source shows a reading of 2000 counts / minute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 105, 483, 120]]<|/det|>
How is the corrected count rate determined?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 510, 149]]<|/det|>
A by moving the detector closer to the source

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 158, 648, 175]]<|/det|>
B by placing an absorber between the detector and the source

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 183, 537, 200]]<|/det|>
C by repeating and averaging the measurements

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 209, 576, 225]]<|/det|>
D by taking away the background radiation count rate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 254, 708, 270]]<|/det|>
36 Which statement about alpha, beta and gamma radiation is not correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 283, 587, 299]]<|/det|>
A Alpha particles are deflected most in an electric field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 308, 581, 325]]<|/det|>
B Beta particles are deflected most in a magnetic field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 333, 595, 351]]<|/det|>
C Gamma radiation is not deflected by a magnetic field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 359, 432, 376]]<|/det|>
D Gamma radiation is least ionising.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 404, 634, 421]]<|/det|>
37 A sample of a radioactive material has a half-life of 20 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 435, 350, 450]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 462, 645, 479]]<|/det|>
A After 30 minutes, less than half of the material has decayed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 488, 650, 504]]<|/det|>
B After 40 minutes, all of the radioactive material has decayed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 513, 669, 530]]<|/det|>
C After 60 minutes, an eighth of the radioactive material remains.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 538, 657, 555]]<|/det|>
D After 120 minutes, a sixth of the radioactive material remains.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 584, 350, 601]]<|/det|>
38 Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 613, 623, 629]]<|/det|>
A The Earth orbits the Sun once in approximately 24 hours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 638, 623, 655]]<|/det|>
B The Earth orbits the Moon once in approximately 1 week.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 664, 631, 681]]<|/det|>
C The Moon orbits the Earth once in approximately 1 month.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 689, 627, 706]]<|/det|>
D The Sun orbits the Earth once in approximately 365 days.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 735, 609, 752]]<|/det|>
39 Stars are powered by nuclear reactions that release energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 765, 640, 782]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes the nuclear reaction in stable stars?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 792, 532, 809]]<|/det|>
A Nuclear fission converts helium into hydrogen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 818, 532, 834]]<|/det|>
B Nuclear fission converts hydrogen into helium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 844, 530, 862]]<|/det|>
C Nuclear fusion converts helium into hydrogen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 870, 530, 886]]<|/det|>
D Nuclear fusion converts hydrogen into helium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 667, 91]]<|/det|>
40 A galaxy is moving away from the Earth at a velocity of 3000 km/s .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 576, 120]]<|/det|>
What is the distance between the Earth and the galaxy?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 131, 263, 149]]<|/det|>
A \(7.3 \times 10^{-25} \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 158, 263, 175]]<|/det|>
B \(7.3 \times 10^{-22} \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 183, 256, 200]]<|/det|>
C \(1.4 \times 10^{21} \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 213, 256, 230]]<|/det|>
D \(1.4 \times 10^{24} \mathrm{~m}\)
